word.entryDescription: a crime of attacking and robbing someone, especially in a public place
word.entryExample: He has been found guilty of mugging.

word.entryDescription: to increase very much in number or amount
word.entryExample: Bacteria multiply slower in low temperatures.

word.entryDescription: to speak quietly and unclearly
word.entryExample: As if we'd know where to go … ,' mumbled Steve.

word.entryDescription: the crime of deliberately killing somebody
word.entryExample: Detectives had suspected the woman of committing the murder for a few months before they found enough evidence to arrest her.

word.entryDescription: a place where people go to look at old or unusual things
word.entryExample: I visited lots of museums when i was in New York.

word.entryDescription: a small soft grey vegetable with a round top used in cooking
word.entryExample: Mushrooms grow in our garden,

word.entryDescription: a pattern of sounds that you make with an instrument that is pleasant to listen to
word.entryExample: I love this music. What's the name of this band?

word.entryDescription: a film or play which includes lots of singing
word.entryExample: I love singing and dancing, so I really like musicals.

word.entryDescription: obligation; used to show that something is necessary or very important, or that it is a rule
word.entryExample: I must help my brother with his homework.

word.entryDescription: (opposite of 'must') obligation; used to show that something is necessary or very important, or that it is a rule
word.entryExample: You mustn't play computer games in the evening.

word.entryDescription: used to refer to the person speaking or writing affected by an action when that person also performs the action
word.entryExample: I remember when I injured myself playing tennis last year.

word.entryDescription: your name is what people call you
word.entryExample: My name is Sam.

word.entryDescription: a description of events, especially in a novel
word.entryExample: At several points the narrative is confusing.

word.entryDescription: having a small distance from one side to the other
word.entryExample: My face is narrow like the rest of my body.

word.entryDescription: extremely unkind and unpleasant
word.entryExample: People think she's nasty because she seems to dislike everyone.

word.entryDescription: a day when most people do not go to work or school, especially because of a religious or national celebration
word.entryExample: Every country celebrates its national holidays.

word.entryDescription: existing in nature; not caused, made, or controlled by people
word.entryExample: Natural extremes of climate include hail, hurricanes and tornadoes.

word.entryDescription: things that exist in nature, such as coal, oil, wood, etc, that are used by humans
word.entryExample: If we all did more recycling, it would help to conserve natural resources.

word.entryDescription: behaving badly
word.entryExample: The puppies are very naughty.

word.entryDescription: the branch of the military that uses mainly ships, boats and submarines
word.entryExample: Athens' money paid jurors and chancellors, built a navy and maintained the army.

word.entryDescription: not far away in distance
word.entryExample: My house is near the river.

word.entryDescription: almost ending in death
word.entryExample: She was in a near-fatal accident.

word.entryDescription: the part of the body between your chest and your head
word.entryExample: A giraffe has a very long neck.

word.entryDescription: a piece of jewellery worn around the neck
word.entryExample: You can either wear a scarf or a necklace, but not both.

word.entryDescription: to have to have or do something, or to want something very much
word.entryExample: I need to buy some flour to make a cake.

word.entryDescription: used when someone should do something or has to do something
word.entryExample: I've got swimming goggles. Do I need to wear them?

word.entryDescription: a small and very thin piece of metal with a point at one end and a hole in the other, used for sewing
word.entryExample: My mum used a needle to repair my trousers.

word.entryDescription: used in negative sentences when something is not necessary
word.entryExample: No, you needn't wear swimming goggles if you don't want to.

word.entryDescription: (usually plural) the process of discussing something formally in order to try to reach an agreement
word.entryExample: After weeks of negotiations, a treaty was finally agreed.

word.entryDescription: somebody who lives next door or very close to you
word.entryExample: That's our neighbour's motorbike.

word.entryDescription: an area of a town or a city; or the people who live there
word.entryExample: It seemed like a good neighbourhood to raise the children.

word.entryDescription: used when a negative statement is also true about another person or thing
word.entryExample: Neither Lucy nor Rachel were late for school.

word.entryDescription: worried or anxious
word.entryExample: I feel nervous before every exam.

word.entryDescription: a place that is built or chosen by animals, particularly birds, in which to lay their eggs, raise their young, live or sleep
word.entryExample: There are three small birds in the nest.

word.entryDescription: something made of string that you have to hit a ball over in tennis, volleyball, etc, or put a ball into in football, basketball, etc
word.entryExample: How high is a tennis net at the centre?

word.entryDescription: a sport similar to basketball, but you can't run with the ball
word.entryExample: I used to like netball, but now I just do sports for P.E., though.

word.entryDescription: a group of people who are in some way connected, e.g. work together or exchange information
word.entryExample: Yoko likes social networks.

word.entryDescription: at no time
word.entryExample: I never play football.

word.entryDescription: something you say to tell somebody not to worry or be upset about something
word.entryExample: Teacher accepted Emma's apology and said 'never mind'.

word.entryDescription: used with a statement which seems surprising or different in contrast to the previous one; however
word.entryExample: The cave was dark and damp. Nevertheless, they decided to go in.

word.entryDescription: something that is new has not been used before
word.entryExample: Is this your new bike?

word.entryDescription: a large city in the United States of America
word.entryExample: Anna lives in New York.

word.entryDescription: someone who works in or owns a shop that sells newspapers, magazines and other small items
word.entryExample: Martin's newsagent needs new paper boys and girls to deliver newspapers and magazines to our customers.

word.entryDescription: being the first one after the present one or the one just mentioned
word.entryExample: What's the next question to our new student?

word.entryDescription: on one side of a person or thing
word.entryExample: This chair next to me is free - you can sit down.

word.entryDescription: a partially processed cocoa bean
word.entryExample: Crushing allows the skin of the seeds to be separated from the nibs, which are cocoa in its purest form.

word.entryDescription: kind or pleasant
word.entryExample: Jill is a very nice girl.

word.entryDescription: the part of the 24-hour day when it is dark
word.entryExample: I don't like travelling at night.

word.entryDescription: a score of zero in many sports
word.entryExample: The match ended one-nil.

word.entryDescription: the number 9
word.entryExample: We have nine guests for dinner tonight.
